condition.description:
Impetigo is a skin infection caused by bacteria. It is usually caused by staphylococcal (staph) bacteria, but it can also be caused by streptococcal (strep) bacteria. It is most common in children between the ages of two and six. It usually starts when bacteria get into a break in the skin, such as a cut, scratch, or insect bite.

Symptoms start with red or pimple-like sores surrounded by red skin. These sores can be anywhere, but usually they occur on your face, arms and legs. The sores fill with pus, then break open after a few days and form a thick crust. They are often itchy, but scratching them can spread the sores.

Impetigo can spread by contact with sores or nasal discharge from an infected person. You can treat impetigo with antibiotics.

NIH: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases
condition.name: Impetigo
symptoms: Red or pimple-like sores surrounded by red skin
Sores can fill with pus, then break open and form a thick crust
Usually on face, arms, or legs

labeled_indications.indication: Due to Staphylococcus aureus (methicillin-susceptible only) or Streptococcus pyogenes

carousel_items: Take this medication exactly as your doctor tells you to.
Take each dose with a meal since it may cause an upset stomach.
If you are taking birth control pills, this can make it less effective.
Store the suspension in the refrigerator. All other forms can be kept at room temperature.

basics.benefits_moa: Augmentin is a combination antibiotic. Amoxicillin kills bacteria and prevents them from reproducing and making their own protective covering. Clavulanate stops chemicals the bacteria make to resist antibiotics.
basics.bottom_line: Augmentin is good for treating many bacterial infections and is available as generic. However, it will make birth control pills less effective. It also has to be taken with food since it can cause an upset stomach.
downsides: If you're on birth control pills, you should use a barrier method (condoms, diaphragms) since Augmentin can make them less effective.
Should be taken with food since it can cause stomach upset.
If you have phenylketonuria (PKU), talk to your doctor to prescribe an alternative.

downsides_processed.orig: If you're on birth control pills, you should use a barrier method (condoms, diaphragms) since Augmentin can make them less effective.
Should be taken with food since it can cause stomach upset.
If you have phenylketonuria (PKU), talk to your doctor to prescribe an alternative.

upsides: Available in different forms: tablet, capsule, and suspension.
Used to treat many types of bacterial infections.
Less resistance seen in bacteria to this antibiotic. Your doctor may run tests to see which antibiotics will kill the bacteria causing your infection.

drugs.name: Augmentin

off-label_indications.indication: Fever and low white blood cell count

carousel_items_processed.orig: Take this medication exactly as your doctor tells you to.
Take each dose with a meal since it may cause an upset stomach.
If you are taking birth control pills, this can make it less effective.
Store the suspension in the refrigerator. All other forms can be kept at room temperature.

risks_warnings.title: Rash
risks_warnings.description: If you have mononucleosis (mono), contact your doctor for alternatives. Taking Augmentin when you have mononucleosis can cause a rash.

description_processed.orig: If you have mononucleosis (mono), contact your doctor for alternatives. Taking Augmentin when you have mononucleosis can cause a rash.

risks_warnings.title: Diarrhea
risks_warnings.description: As with all antibiotics, Augmentin can cause diarrhea. If this happens while you're taking the medication, taking probiotics in the form of yogurt, supplements or drinks a few hours after you take the medication may help. If you develop an unusual diarrhea with loose or bloody stools weeks after you finish the medication, talk to your doctor as this can be a rare but serious side effect.

description_processed.orig: As with all antibiotics, Augmentin can cause diarrhea. If this happens while you're taking the medication, taking probiotics in the form of yogurt, supplements or drinks a few hours after you take the medication may help. If you develop an unusual diarrhea with loose or bloody stools weeks after you finish the medication, talk to your doctor as this can be a rare but serious side effect.

risks_warnings.title: Liver damage
risks_warnings.description: There have been reports of liver damage that can require hospitalization or can cause death. These have been rare. Talk to your doctor if you notice pain in your abdomen, loss of appetite, yellowing of your skin or eyes, or dark colored urine.

description_processed.orig: There have been reports of liver damage that can require hospitalization or can cause death. These have been rare. Talk to your doctor if you notice pain in your abdomen, loss of appetite, yellowing of your skin or eyes, or dark colored urine.

risks_warnings.title: Decreased effectiveness of birth control pills
risks_warnings.description: If you are taking Augmentin and you are also on birth control pills, the birth control can become less effective. Consider using a barrier form of birth control (condoms, diaphragms, etc.) while taking Augmentin.

description_processed.orig: If you are taking Augmentin and you are also on birth control pills, the birth control can become less effective. Consider using a barrier form of birth control (condoms, diaphragms, etc.) while taking Augmentin.

carousel_items: Very commonly used topical antibiotic to treat acne.
The only topical erythromycin in a gel formula.
Apply a thin film to clean and dry affected skin once or twice a day.
It may take 6-8 weeks before you see improvement in your acne.
Avoid getting into your eyes, nose or mouth.
Let your doctor know if you notice abdominal discomfort, pain or diarrhea after starting this medicine.
Using a moisturizer that doesn't block your pores (non-comedogenic) may help lessen common side effects of skin dryness and peeling.
Taking good care of your skin is an important part of treating acne. Lightly wash with warm water and non-soap-based or gentle cleanser.

basics.benefits_moa: Erythromycin is a topical antibiotic. It fights bacteria that cause acne in oil (sebaceous) glands, and contains alcohol which dries out acne-affected areas.
basics.bottom_line: Erythromycin is a very common acne treatment you apply to the skin that may work better when combined with other topical medicines.
downsides: There's a risk of irritation with anything you apply to your skin and this is no different. erythromycin, like other topical antibiotics, can cause skin irritation and may appear as redness, peeling, abnormal dryness or stinging, tightening, or burning sensations.
It's rare, that a serious allergic reaction would occur, but it's a good idea to test a small area of skin before using on any larger or sensitive areas
Studies show it works better when combined with other topical medicines to fight acne and reduce the risk of it losing its effectiveness over time.
Can cause severe inflammation of the large intestine (pseudomembranous colitis)
Stop using if you don't notice any improvement in your acne after 6-8 weeks. The most time you can use it is three months.

downsides_processed.orig: There's a risk of irritation with anything you apply to your skin and this is no different. erythromycin, like other topical antibiotics, can cause skin irritation and may appear as redness, peeling, abnormal dryness or stinging, tightening, or burning sensations.
It's rare, that a serious allergic reaction would occur, but it's a good idea to test a small area of skin before using on any larger or sensitive areas
Studies show it works better when combined with other topical medicines to fight acne and reduce the risk of it losing its effectiveness over time.
Can cause severe inflammation of the large intestine (pseudomembranous colitis)
Stop using if you don't notice any improvement in your acne after 6-8 weeks. The most time you can use it is three months.

upsides: Applying erythromycin to the skin reduces the amount of acne bacteria and "calms" the skin down (lowers the inflammatory response) in acne.
Available in a gel formulation which may be better if your skin is very oily.
Better choice if you're pregnant. erythromycin is categorized as pregnancy Category B (likely safe) as compared to similar topical medicines that are Category C (weigh risks vs benefits).

upsides_processed.orig: Applying erythromycin to the skin reduces the amount of acne bacteria and "calms" the skin down (lowers the inflammatory response) in acne.
Available in a gel formulation which may be better if your skin is very oily.
Better choice if you're pregnant. erythromycin is categorized as pregnancy Category B (likely safe) as compared to similar topical medicines that are Category C (weigh risks vs benefits).

drugs.name: Erygel

carousel_items_processed.orig: Very commonly used topical antibiotic to treat acne.
The only topical erythromycin in a gel formula.
Apply a thin film to clean and dry affected skin once or twice a day.
It may take 6-8 weeks before you see improvement in your acne.
Avoid getting into your eyes, nose or mouth.
Let your doctor know if you notice abdominal discomfort, pain or diarrhea after starting this medicine.
Using a moisturizer that doesn't block your pores (non-comedogenic) may help lessen common side effects of skin dryness and peeling.
Taking good care of your skin is an important part of treating acne. Lightly wash with warm water and non-soap-based or gentle cleanser.

risks_warnings.title: Allergic reaction
risks_warnings.description: Rarely, Erythromycin can cause serious allergic reactions and life-threatening organ failure. Report any skin rash, fever, swelling, or trouble breathing to a doctor immediately. It may occur immediately longer, after continued use.

description_processed.orig: Rarely, Erythromycin can cause serious allergic reactions and life-threatening organ failure. Report any skin rash, fever, swelling, or trouble breathing to a doctor immediately. It may occur immediately longer, after continued use.

risks_warnings.title: Skin irritation
risks_warnings.description: Erythromycin may cause skin redness, burning, peeling or swelling. It might improve if you use a formula that weaker, or less often.
risk_factors: Using other medicines or products that irritate the skin

description_processed.orig: Erythromycin may cause skin redness, burning, peeling or swelling. It might improve if you use a formula that weaker, or less often.

risks_warnings.title: Development of more serious infections
risks_warnings.description: Although the amount of Erythromycin that's absorbed in the body is very low when it's applied to the skin, using it for a long period of time can cause a fungal infection or more serious bacterial infection including c-difficile diarrhea and severe colitis.  It can happen more than 2 months after stopping treatment. If you develop significant diarrhea while taking Erythromycin or after stopping it, let you doctor know right away.

description_processed.orig: Although the amount of Erythromycin that's absorbed in the body is very low when it's applied to the skin, using it for a long period of time can cause a fungal infection or more serious bacterial infection including c-difficile diarrhea and severe colitis.  It can happen more than 2 months after stopping treatment. If you develop significant diarrhea while taking Erythromycin or after stopping it, let you doctor know right away.

carousel_items: Take it with or without food.
It's dosed based on your weight, so different people will have different doses.
If you're using the suspension, refrigerate it and use it within 10 days.

It's common to feel better before you're supposed to stop taking Erythromycin, but make sure to take it for the entire time your doctor prescribed it. Skipping doses or stopping early can lower the drug's effectiveness and increase the chance that the drug won't work as well next time.

basics.benefits_moa: Erythromycin is a macrolide antibiotic that prevents and treats a variety of infections. It works by preventing bacteria from growing and multiplying.
basics.bottom_line: Erythromycin works well to treat a variety of bacterial infections, but check for drug interactions before taking it.
downsides: Interacts with a lot of drugs, so don't take it with colchicine, statin drugs, verapamil, amlodipine, or diltiazem.
Diarrhea and other stomach problems are common side effects.
Can cause liver problems, so people with previous liver problems need to be closely monitored while on Erythromycin.

downsides_processed.orig: Interacts with a lot of drugs, so don't take it with colchicine, statin drugs, verapamil, amlodipine, or diltiazem.
Diarrhea and other stomach problems are common side effects.
Can cause liver problems, so people with previous liver problems need to be closely monitored while on Erythromycin.

upsides: It's used to treat a variety of infections caused by bacteria.
It comes as an oral suspension and as a tablet.
You can get a test done that'll show you if Erythromycin will work for you.

upsides_processed.orig: It's used to treat a variety of infections caused by bacteria.
It comes as an oral suspension and as a tablet.
You can get a test done that'll show you if Erythromycin will work for you.

drugs.name: Erythromycin

carousel_items_processed.orig: Take it with or without food.
It's dosed based on your weight, so different people will have different doses.
If you're using the suspension, refrigerate it and use it within 10 days.

It's common to feel better before you're supposed to stop taking Erythromycin, but make sure to take it for the entire time your doctor prescribed it. Skipping doses or stopping early can lower the drug's effectiveness and increase the chance that the drug won't work as well next time.

risks_warnings.title: Liver damage
risks_warnings.description: There have been reports of liver damage that can require hospitalization or can cause death. These have been rare. Talk to your doctor if you notice pain in your abdomen, loss of appetite, yellowing of your skin or eyes, or dark colored urine.

description_processed.orig: There have been reports of liver damage that can require hospitalization or can cause death. These have been rare. Talk to your doctor if you notice pain in your abdomen, loss of appetite, yellowing of your skin or eyes, or dark colored urine.

risks_warnings.title: Heart rate problems
risks_warnings.description: Erythromycin can cause a dangerous arrhythmias called QT interval prolongation and torsades de pointes. Erythromycin should be avoided in people who have had arrhythmias in the past. Elderly people are more likely to have this side effect.

description_processed.orig: Erythromycin can cause a dangerous arrhythmias called QT interval prolongation and torsades de pointes. Erythromycin should be avoided in people who have had arrhythmias in the past. Elderly people are more likely to have this side effect.

risks_warnings.title: Diarrhea from a superinfection
risks_warnings.description: Taking antibiotics, like Erythromycin can increase your chance of getting certain fungal or bacterial infections that causes diarrhea and can be contagious. This is a superinfection, an infection that happens after, or in addition to, an earlier infection. If you develop an unusual diarrhea with loose or bloody stools weeks after you finish the medication, talk to your doctor since this can be a rare but serious side effect.

description_processed.orig: Taking antibiotics, like Erythromycin can increase your chance of getting certain fungal or bacterial infections that causes diarrhea and can be contagious. This is a superinfection, an infection that happens after, or in addition to, an earlier infection. If you develop an unusual diarrhea with loose or bloody stools weeks after you finish the medication, talk to your doctor since this can be a rare but serious side effect.

carousel_items: Take this medication exactly as your doctor tells you to.
Store the suspension in the refrigerator. All other forms can be kept at room temperature.
Space out vitamins by a couple hours if you're taking this medication.

basics.benefits_moa: Cephalexin is an antibiotic. It kills bacteria by preventing them from making their own protective covering.
basics.bottom_line: Cephalexin is good for treating many bacterial infections and is available as generic. However, if you are on medications to thin your blood, you can be more likely to bleed.
downsides: If you're on blood thinners (anticoagulants), talk to your doctor, it may make you more likely to bleed.
If you have to take any live vaccines, talk to your doctor. You may have to postpone it.

downsides_processed.orig: If you're on blood thinners (anticoagulants), talk to your doctor, it may make you more likely to bleed.
If you have to take any live vaccines, talk to your doctor. You may have to postpone it.

upsides: Available in different forms: tablet, capsule, and suspension.
Used to treat many types of bacterial infections.
Less resistance seen in bacteria to this antibiotic. Your doctor may run tests to see which antibiotics will kill the bacteria causing your infection.
Can be taken with or without food.

upsides_processed.orig: Available in different forms: tablet, capsule, and suspension.

userStories.tip: I was told that I could take it 2 times a day (2 capsules at a time) instead of 1 four times a day. Huge difference in ease of use!
